case_name: Kunwar Rananjaya Singh v. Baijnath Singh

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 73 of 1954 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 73 of 1954.

facts.text: Appeal by Special Leave against the Judgment and Order dated 11th February 1954 of the Election Tribunal Allahabad in Election Petition No. 252 of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by Special Leave against the Judgment and Order dated the 11th day of February, 1954, of the Election Tribunal, Allahabad. in Election Petition No. 252 of 1952.

facts.text: Judgment of the Supreme Court delivered on September 29, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: 1954. September 29. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by DAB J.

facts.text: Kunwar Rananjaya Singh is the son of Raja Bhagwan Bux Singh of Amethi.

anchor.surface_text: Kunwar Rananjaya Singh, the appellant before us, is the son of Raja Bhagwan Bux Singh of Amethi.

facts.text: Kunwar Rananjaya Singh was the successful candidate at an election to the Uttar Pradesh Legislative Assembly from Amethi Central constituency.

anchor.surface_text: He was the successful candidate at an election to the Uttar Pradesh Legislative Assembly from Amethi Central companystituency

facts.text: Polling took place on 31st January 1952.

anchor.surface_text: the polling in respect of which took place on the 31st January, 1952, and the result whereof

facts.text: Election result announced on 6th February 1952.

anchor.surface_text: and the result whereof was announced on the 6th February, 1952, and finally published

facts.text: Result published in Uttar Pradesh State Gazette on 26th February 1952.

anchor.surface_text: published in the Uttar Pradesh State Gazette on the 26th February, 1952.

facts.text: Baijnath Singh, unsuccessful candidate, filed election petition challenging the election of Kunwar Rananjaya Singh.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, Baijnath Singh, who was one of the unsuccessful candidates filed an election petition calling in question the election of the appellant.

facts.text: Election challenged on grounds of corrupt practices including bribery, undue influence, publication of false and defamatory statements, and concealment of election expenses.

anchor.surface_text: The grounds on which the election was challenged were that the appellant himself, together with his own and his fathers servants and other dependents and agents, companymitted various companyrupt practices of bribery, exercise of undue influence, publication of false and defamatory statements and companycealment of election expenses

facts.text: Baijnath Singh prayed that election be set aside and he be declared duly elected.

anchor.surface_text: He prayed that the election of the appellant be set aside and that he, the said respondent, be declared to have been duly elected.

facts.text: Appellant denied all charges of corrupt practices in written statement.

anchor.surface_text: In his written statement he denied each and every one of the charges of companyrupt practices levelled against him

facts.text: Appellant filed petition of recrimination challenging conduct of Baijnath Singh.

anchor.surface_text: and he also filed a petition of recrimination challenging the companyduct of the said respondent at the election.

facts.text: Baijnath Singh denied charges in recrimination.

anchor.surface_text: The said respondent denied the charges imputed to him.

facts.text: 15 issues raised: 8 on election petition and 7 on recrimination.

anchor.surface_text: Altogether 15 issues were raised, namely, eight. on the election petition and 7 on the petition of -recrimination.

facts.text: Election Tribunal found all 7 recrimination issues against appellant and dismissed recrimination petition.

anchor.surface_text: All the 7 issues arising out of the petition of recrimination were found by the tribunal companystituted for hearing of the election petition against the appellant and the petition of recrimination was dismissed.

facts.text: Election Tribunal decided issue No. 3 against appellant.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the issues arising on the main election petition the election tribunal found in favour of the appellant on issues Nos. 1, 2, 4,5, 6 and 7 but decided issue No. 3 against the appellant.

facts.text: Issue No. 3: Did respondent No. 1 employ more persons than authorised, incur concealed expenditures, exceed limit.

anchor.surface_text: That issue was as follows3 Did respondent No. I employ for election more persons than authorised by law? Did respondent No. I incur the expenditure shown in the list as Heads of other companycealed expenditures? Did he exceed the prescribed limit of expenditure for election ?

facts.text: Election Tribunal held appellant guilty of employing about 20 Ziladars of Amethi estate, their peons and orderlies (item ii).

anchor.surface_text: Item  ii  charred that all the paid Ziladars of Amethi estate who were about 20 in number assisted by their peons and orderlies worked for the appellant

facts.text: Election Tribunal held Manager and Assistant Manager of Amethi estate worked for appellant (item iii).

anchor.surface_text: item No.  iii  companyplained that the Manager and the Assistant Manager of that estate also worked for him.

facts.text: Election Tribunal found number of these persons exceeded prescribed limit and their salaries would exceed maximum Rs. 8,000.

anchor.surface_text: The tribunal held that the number of all these persons companying within these two categories far exceeded the prescribed number of persons who companyld be employed in an election and their salary for the period they worked for the appellant in companynection with the election, if added to the admitted election expenses, would exceed the maximum expenditure permissible

facts.text: Maximum election expense for single-member constituency in Uttar Pradesh is Rs. 8,000 as per Schedule V.

anchor.surface_text: The maximum amount specified in that schedule in respect of a singl emember companystituency in the Uttar Pradesh is only Rs. 8,000.

facts.text: Election Tribunal declared election of appellant void.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the tribunal under the general issue No. 8 only declared the election of the appellant to be void.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave for appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Hence this appeal filed by the unseated candidate with the special leave of this Court.

facts.text: Amethi estate belonged to father of appellant.

anchor.surface_text: that although the estate belonged to the father of the appellant, nevertheless, as the appellant was the heir apparent

facts.text: Appellant looked after the estate on behalf of old and infirm proprietor.

anchor.surface_text: nevertheless, as the appellant was the heir apparent and actually looked after the estate on behalf of the old and infirm proprietor,

facts.text: Advocate for respondent conceded he could not support tribunal's finding that estate servants were appellant's.

anchor.surface_text: The Learned advocate appear ing for the respondent frankly and properly companyceded that he companyld number support this part of the finding of the tribunal.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that servants were employed and paid by father, not by appellant.

anchor.surface_text: There can be numberdoubt that in the eye of the law these extra persons were in the employment of the father of the appellant and paid by the father and they were neither employed number paid by the appellant.

facts.text: Supreme Court held appellant not guilty of corrupt practice under section 123(7).

anchor.surface_text: we are of opinion that the appellant cannot in the circumstances of this case be held to be guilty of any companyrupt practice under section 123 7  as alleged against him.

facts.text: Supreme Court held appellant not guilty of minor corrupt practice under section 124(4).

anchor.surface_text: It follows from this that number having incurred any expenditure over and above what was shown by him in his return of election expenses he cannot be said to have companycealed such expenditure and, therefore, he cannot be held to have been guilty of any minor companyrupt practice under section 124 4  of the Act.
Appeal by Special Leave against the Judgment and Order dated the 11th day of February, 1954, of the Election Tribunal, Allahabad. in Election Petition No. 252 of 1952.

In the result, the tribunal under the general issue No. 8 only declared the election of the appellant to be void. Hence this appeal filed by the unseated candidate with the special leave of this Court.

Hence this appeal filed by the unseated candidate with the special leave of this Court. Section 77 of the Representation of the People Act, 1951, provides that the maximum scales of election expenses at elections and the numbers and descriptions of persons who may be employed for payment in compannection with election shall be as may be prescribed.

concepts.interpretation: Must be read consistent with section 123(7); prohibits employment and expenditure by candidate or agent.

anchor.surface_text: Schedule VI allows I election agent, 1 companynting agent, 1 clerk and 1 messenger at all elections. It also allows, in addition to these, 1 clerk and 1 messenger for every 75,000 electors and 1 polling agent and 2 relief agents for each polling booth and I messenger at each polling booth.

The provisions of rules 117 and 118 are to be read in the light of this definition of a companyrupt practice. Indeed, these rules follow the language of section 123 7  in that they prohibit the employment of persons other than or in addition to those specified in Schedule VI, and the incurring or authorising of expenditure in excess of the amount. specified in Schedule V, and in both cases by a candidate or his agent. Section 77 must, therefore, be read in a manner companysonant with section 123 7  and rule 117 and and 11 8.

concepts.interpretation: Section 77 read consistent with section 123(7) and rules 117, 118.

issues.text: Did respondent No. 1 employ for election more persons than authorised by law? Did respondent No. 1 incur the expenditure shown in the list as Heads of other concealed expenditures? Did he exceed the prescribed limit of expenditure for election?

anchor.surface_text: That issue was as follows3 Did respondent No. I employ for election more persons than authorised by law? Did respondent No. I incur the expenditure shown in the list as Heads of other companycealed expenditures? Did he exceed the prescribed limit of expenditure for election ?

issues.text: Whether the Manager, Assistant Manager, 20 Ziladars of Amethi estate and their peons and orderlies had been employed for payment by the appellant?

anchor.surface_text: The charge against the appellant was, inter alia, that the Manager, Assistant Manager, 20 Ziladars of Amethi estate and their peons and orderlies had worked for the appellant in companynection with the election. The tribunal took the view-we think quite erroneously that although the estate belonged to the father of the appellant, nevertheless, as the appellant was the heir apparent and actually looked after the estate on behalf of the old and infirm proprietor, these servants of the estate were virtually his own servants and could properly be regarded as having been employed for payment by the appellant.

issues.text: Whether excess number of persons employed for payment brings the case within section 77 irrespective of who employed or paid them?

anchor.surface_text: He, however, contended, relying on the language used in section 77, that if the number of persons who worked for payment in companynection with the election exceeded the maximum number specified in Schedule VI, the case fell within the mischief of the relevant sections and the rules, numbermatter who employed them or who made payments to them.

issues.text: Whether section 77 must be read in a manner consonant with section 123(7) and rules 117 and 118?

anchor.surface_text: The provisions of rules 117 and 118 are to be read in the light of this definition of a companyrupt practice. Indeed, these rules follow the language of section 123 7  in that they prohibit the employment of persons other than or in addition to those specified in Schedule VI, and the incurring or authorising of expenditure in excess of the amount. specified in Schedule V, and in both cases by a candidate or his agent. Section 77 must, therefore, be read in a manner companysonant with section 123 7  and rule 117 and and 11 8.

issues.text: Whether the appellant was guilty of a minor corrupt practice under section 124(4)?

anchor.surface_text: The case, therefore, does number fall within section 123 7  at all and if that be so, it cannot companye within section 124 4 .

issues.text: Whether the election of the appellant is void?

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the tribunal under the general issue No. 8 only declared the election of the appellant to be void. Hence this appeal filed by the unseated candidate with the special leave of this Court.

issues.text: Whether, if one's own servants are also utilised or employed in the conduct of the election, their salary for the period they are so utilised or employed should be regarded as election expenses and shown in the return?

anchor.surface_text: In the view we have taken, namely, that these extra men were number employed or paid by the appellant, it is unnecessary, for the purpose of this appeal, to discuss the question whether, if ones own servants are also utilised or employed in the companyduct of the election, their salary for the period they are so utilised or employed should be regarded as election expenses and shown in the return.

arguments.claim: Servants of Amethi estate (Ziladars, peons, manager, assistant manager) were employed for payment by appellant as they virtually belonged to him being heir apparent who looked after estate.

anchor.surface_text: The charge against the appellant was, inter alia, that the Manager, Assistant Manager, 20 Ziladars of Amethi estate and their peons and orderlies had worked for the appellant in connection with the election. The tribunal took the view-we think quite erroneously that although the estate belonged to the father of the a

arguments.court_reasoning: Quite erroneously; servants employed and paid by father.

arguments.claim: If number of persons working for payment exceeded limit under Schedule VI, case falls within s77, rules 117/118, s123(7) regardless of who employed or paid them.

anchor.surface_text: He, however, contended, relying on the language used in section 77, that if the number of persons who worked for payment in connection with the election exceeded the maximum number specified in Schedule VI, the case fell within the mischief of the relevant sections and the rules, no matter who employed them or who made payments to them.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: his own servants and companyld properly be regarded as having been employed for payment by the appellant. The Learned advocate appear ing for the resp

arguments.court_reasoning: Gist of s123(7) requires by candidate/agent; s77 read consonant with s123(7), rules 117/118.

arguments.claim: S77 must be read consonant with s123(7) and rules 117/118 which require excess employment/expenditure by candidate or agent only.

anchor.surface_text: The provisions of rules 117 and 118 are to be read in the light of this definition of a corrupt practice. Indeed, these rules follow the language of section 123(7) in that they prohibit the employment of persons other than or in addition to those specified in Schedule VI, and the incurring or authorising of expenditure in excess of the amount specified in Schedule V, and in both cases by a candidate or his agent. Section 77 must, therefore, be read in a manner consonant with section 123(7) and rule 117 and 118.

arguments.claim: Observation of Phillimore J. in Joseph Forster Wilson v. Sir Christopher Furness supports that excess employment must be by candidate.

anchor.surface_text: In this view of the matter the observation made by Phillimore J. in Joseph Forster Wilson and, Another v. Sir Christopher Furness 1 , relied on by the appellant and referred to in the judgment of the tribunal are quite apposite.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: r v. Sir Christopher Furness 1 , relied on by the appellant and referred to in the judgment of the tribunal are quite apposite. There can be numberdou

arguments.claim: Literal construction allowing rich relations' help is against spirit of election laws giving unfair advantage to rich candidates.

anchor.surface_text: The learned advocate, however, contended that such a construction would be against the spirit of the election laws in that candidates who have rich friends or relations would have an unfair advantage over a poor rival. The spirit of the law may well be an elusive and unsafe guide and the supposed spirit can certainly not be given effect to in opposition to the plain language of the sections of the Act and the rules made there under.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: and paid by him for working in the estate. At the request of the father they assisted the son in companynection with the election which strictly speak

arguments.court_reasoning: Spirit elusive and unsafe guide; cannot override plain language.

arguments.claim: Supposed spirit of law cannot override plain language of Act and rules.

anchor.surface_text: The spirit of the law may well be an elusive and unsafe guide and the supposed spirit can certainly not be given effect to in opposition to the plain language of the sections of the Act and the rules made there under. If all that can be said of these statutory provisions is that construed according to the ordinary, grammatical and natural meaning of their language they work injustice by placing the poorer candidates at a disadvantage the appeal must be to Parliament and not to this Court.

arguments.claim: Appellant guilty of corrupt practice under s123(7) for excess persons employed and expenditure exceeding limit.

anchor.surface_text: The tribunal, therefore, held that the appellant was guilty, under both these heads, of corrupt practice as defined, in section 123(7) of the Representation of the People Act, 1951, and was consequently liable to be dealt with under section 100(2)(b) and section 145 of that Act.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: election laws in that candidates who have rich friends or relations would have an unfair advantage

arguments.claim: Appellant guilty of minor corrupt practice under s124(4) for concealing excess election expenses in return.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant was also guilty of a minor corrupt practice as defined in section 124(4) of the Act and was liable to be dealt with under section 100(2)(a) and section 145 of the Act.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: irit. can certainly number be given effect to in opposition to the plain language of the sections of

arguments.court_reasoning: No excess expenditure incurred by appellant, hence no concealment.

arguments.claim: Respondent No.1 employed more persons than authorised, incurred concealed expenditures, exceeded expense limit (issue 3).

anchor.surface_text: That issue was as follows: Did respondent No. I employ for election more persons than authorised by law? Did respondent No. I incur the expenditure shown in the list as Heads of other concealed expenditures? Did he exceed the prescribed limit of expenditure for election ?

court_response_anchor.surface_text: election laws in that candidates who have rich friends or relations would have an unfair advantage over a poor rival. The spirit of the law may well

arguments.court_reasoning: No employment or payment by appellant.

arguments.claim: Servants were volunteers qua appellant as employed/paid by father; equivalent to holiday on pay and voluntary help.

anchor.surface_text: There can be no doubt that in the eye of the law these extra persons were in the employment of the father of the appellant and paid by the father and they were neither employed nor paid by the appellant. ... Was the position in law at all different from the position that the father had given these employees a holiday on full pay and they voluntarily rendered assistance to the appellant in connection with his election? We think not.

holdings.text: The servants of the Amethi estate (Ziladars, peons, orderlies, manager, assistant manager) were employed and paid by the appellant's father, not by the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: There can be numberdoubt that in the eye of the law these extra persons were in the employment of the father of the appellant and paid by the father and they were neither employed number paid by the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal's view erroneous; respondent conceded; in eye of law employed by father; equivalent to paid holiday and voluntary help.

holdings.text: Section 77 must be read in a manner consonant with section 123(7) and rules 117 and 118, requiring employment and expenditure by candidate or agent.

anchor.surface_text: The provisions of rules 117 and 118 are to be read in the light of this definition of a corrupt practice. Indeed, these rules follow the language of section 123 7  in that they prohibit the employment of persons other than or in addition to those specified in Schedule VI, and the incurring or authorising of expenditure in excess of the amount. specified in Schedule V, and in both cases by a candidate or his agent. Section 77 must, therefore, be read in a manner companysonant with section 123 7  and rule 117 and and 11 8.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rules follow language of s123(7); gist of corrupt practice is action by candidate/agent; harmonious construction required.

holdings.text: Excess persons working irrespective of who employed or paid them does not constitute corrupt practice under relevant provisions.

anchor.surface_text: but it must be borne in mind that the gist -of a corrupt practice as defined in section 123 7  is that the employment of extra persons and the incurring or authorising of excess expenditure -must be by the candidate or his agent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects respondent's literal reading of s77 alone; must align with s123(7) requiring candidate/agent involvement.

holdings.text: The appellant is not guilty of any corrupt practice under section 123(7).

anchor.surface_text: we are of opinion that the appellant cannot in the circumstances of this case be held to be guilty of any companyrupt practice under section 123 7  as alleged against him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No employment or payment by appellant; persons were father's employees acting as volunteers qua appellant.

holdings.text: The appellant is not guilty of any minor corrupt practice under section 124(4).

anchor.surface_text: It follows from this that number having incurred any expenditure over and above what was shown by him in his return of election expenses he cannot be said to have companycealed such expenditure and, therefore, he cannot be held to have been guilty of any minor companyrupt practice under section 124 4  of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No excess expenditure incurred by appellant, hence no concealment.

holdings.text: The election of the appellant is not void.

anchor.surface_text: we are of opinion that the appellant cannot in the circumstances of this case be held to be guilty of any companyrupt practice under section 123 7  as alleged against him. It follows from this that number having incurred any expenditure over and above what was shown by him in his return of election expenses he cannot be said to have companycealed such expenditure and, therefore, he cannot be held to have been guilty of any minor companyrupt practice under section 124 4  of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Absence of corrupt or minor corrupt practices; reverses tribunal's declaration under s100.

holdings.text: Supposed spirit of the law cannot override the plain language of the Act and rules; literal construction applies.

anchor.surface_text: The learned advocate, however, companytended that such a companystruction would be against the spirit of the election laws in that candidates who have rich friends or relations would have an unfair advantage over a poor rival. The spirit of the law may well be an elusive and unsafe guide and the supposed spirit. can certainly number be given effect to in opposition to the plain language of the sections of the Act and the rules made there under.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Spirit is elusive/unsafe guide; ordinary grammatical meaning prevails; remedy lies with Parliament.

anchor.surface_text: The provisions of rules 117 and 118 are to be read in the light of this definition of a corrupt practice. Indeed, these rules follow the language of section 123 7  in that they prohibit the employment of persons other than or in addition to those specified in Schedule VI, and the incurring or authorising of expenditure in excess of the amount. specified in Schedule V, and in both cases by a candidate or his agent. Section 77 must, therefore, be read in a manner companysonant with section 123 7  and rule 117 and and 11 8.
